sentences: Kenneth Arnold Chesney  (born March 26, 1968) is an American country music singer, songwriter, guitarist, musician, and record producer.
section: N/A

sentences: He has recorded more than 20 albums and has produced more than 40 Top 10 singles on the US Billboard Hot Country Songs and Country Airplay charts, 32 of which have reached number one.
section: N/A

sentences: Many of these have also charted within the Top 40 of the US Billboard Hot 100, making him one of the most successful crossover country artists.
section: N/A

sentences: He has sold over 30 million albums worldwide.
section: N/A

sentences: He has received six Academy of Country Music awards (including four consecutive Entertainer of the Year awards from 2005 to 2008), as well as nine awards from the Country Music Association.
section: N/A

sentences: He is one of the most popular touring acts in country music, regularly selling out the venues in which he performs.
section: N/A

sentences: His 2007 Flip-Flop Summer Tour was the highest-grossing country road trip of the year.
section: N/A

sentences: The Country Music Association honored Chesney with the Entertainer of the Year award in 2005, 2006, 2007, and 2008.
section: N/A

sentences: Other notable awards he received include the Academy of Country  Music's 1997 New Male Vocalist of the Year, 2002 Top Male Vocalist of the Year, and the Triple Crown Award in 2005.
section: N/A

sentences: He was awarded his fourth consecutive Entertainer of the Year award from the Academy of Country Music on May 18, 2008.

== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Chesney was born on March 26, 1968, in Knoxville, Tennessee, United States, at St. Mary's Medical Center and was raised in Luttrell.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He is of English and Irish descent.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He is the son of David Chesney, a former elementary school teacher, and Karen Chandler, a hair stylist in the Knoxville area.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Chesney has one sibling, a younger sister named Jennifer Chandler.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 1986, Chesney graduated from Gibbs High School, where he played baseball and football.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He received his first guitar, "The Terminor", for Christmas and began teaching himself how to play it.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Chesney studied advertising at East Tennessee State University in Johnson City, where he was a member of the ETSU Bluegrass Program and the Lambda Chi Alpha fraternity and graduated in 1990.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 1989, he recorded a self-released demo album at the Classic Recording Studio in Bristol, Virginia.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He sold 1,000 copies while performing at the local clubs in Johnson City and used the money from album sales to help himself buy a new guitar.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: After graduation from East Tennessee State in 1990, he headed to Nashville and performed at several local clubs, including The Bluebird Cafe.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He became the resident performer at The Turf, a honky tonk bar in the city's historic district.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Signing first publishing and record deals ===
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: In 1992, the head of writer relations at BMI, Clay Bradley, recommended Chesney to his friend, Troy Tomlinson, at Opryland Music Group by saying: "I met this kid today from East Tennessee.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: He's a good singer, a good songwriter, and more than anything, I think you're going to really like him as a person."
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: Chesney performed five songs during his audition for Tomlinson.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: Tomlinson's reaction was enthusiastic, later telling HitQuarters:
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: First of all I was attracted to the songs, because I thought that he painted great pictures in his lyrics, particularly for someone who had not been around the typical Music Row co-writes.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: I thought that he sang very well too.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: But more than anything there was a kind of this 'I-will-do-it' look in his eyes – I was really drawn in by the fact that he was so set on being successful in this business.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: Chesney left the audition with a songwriter's contract.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

sentences: A year later, an appearance at a songwriter's showcase led to a contract with Capricorn Records, which had recently started a country division.
section: == Career and awards == | === Signing first publishing and record deals ===

section: == Career and awards == | === Lucky Old Sun (2008–2009) ===

sentences: The tour included a performance at Gillette Stadium again, marking the fifth year in a row that he played at the Foxboro, Massachusetts football field.
section: == Career and awards == | === Lucky Old Sun (2008–2009) ===

sentences: In this same period, Chesney produced a film for ESPN titled The Boys of Fall (2010).
section: == Career and awards == | === Lucky Old Sun (2008–2009) ===

sentences: This album included the No. 1 hit, "Out Last Night", as the lead single.
section: == Career and awards == | === Greatest Hits II (2010) ===

sentences: Also included on this album is one that Willie Nelson recorded before Chesney did, "I'm Alive".

sentences: In July 2010, Chesney released "The Boys of Fall" as the lead-off single from his album Hemingway's Whiskey, which was released in September 2010.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: The song hit No. 1 on the Hot Country Songs chart for the week of October 9, 2010, marking Chesney's eighteenth number one hit.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: He then appeared at the 44th Annual Country Music Awards on November 10, 2010.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: The second single from Hemingway's Whiskey, "Somewhere with You", was released in November 2010.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: The song debuted at No. 35 on the country chart for the week of November 6, 2010.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: Both it and its followup, "Live a Little", went to number 1 on the country charts.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: The next single was "You and Tequila", co-written and originally recorded by Deana Carter.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: Chesney's rendition, which featured Grace Potter on backing vocals, went to number 3.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: After it, "Reality" also went to number 1.
section: == Career and awards == | === Hemingway's Whiskey (2010–2011) ===

sentences: Chesney produced and narrated a biographical film, The Color Orange, on his favorite football player growing up, University of Tennessee quarterback and Canadian Football League hall-of-fame Condredge Holloway.

sentences: The film was produced for ESPN's "Year of the Quarterback" series, and premiered on February 20, 2011.

sentences: Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012)
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===
== Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: Chesney released his fourteenth studio album, Welcome to the Fishbowl, on June 19, 2012.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: Its lead-off single, a Tim McGraw duet titled "Feel Like a Rock Star", debuted at number 13 on the country charts, making it the second-highest debuting country song since the Billboard charts were first tabulated via Nielsen SoundScan, and the highest-debuting duet on that chart.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: Despite its high debut, the song peaked at number 11 only six weeks later before falling.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: BNA Records closed in June 2012.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: As a result, Chesney was transferred to Columbia Nashville.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: His first release under Columbia was the album's second single, "Come Over", which went to number 1.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: The album's third and final single was "El Cerrito Place", which was written by Keith Gattis and originally recorded by Charlie Robison.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: Chesney's rendition, which featured Grace Potter on backing vocals, went to number 10 on the country charts.
section: == Career and awards == | === Welcome to the Fishbowl (2012) ===

sentences: Chesney released his fifteenth studio album, Life on a Rock, on April 30, 2013.

sentences: The first single from the album, "Pirate Flag", was released to iTunes on February 5, 2013 and peaked at number 3 on the Country Airplay chart in May 2013.
section: == Career and awards == | === Life on a Rock (2013) ===

sentences: Pirate Flag peaked at number 7 on Billboard's Hot Country Songs chart, May 25, 2013.
section: == Career and awards == | === Life on a Rock (2013) ===

sentences: The album's second single, "When I See This Bar", was released to country radio on June 10, 2013.
section: == Career and awards == | === Life on a Rock (2013) ===

sentences: When I see This Bar peaked at number 25 on Billboard's Hot Country Songs chart, September 14, 2013.

sentences: This specific album was a drastic change from his regular country feel, to an all beach and island touch.

sentences: In June 2014, Chesney released the new song "American Kids" to radio.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: This song served as the lead-off single from his sixteenth studio album The Big Revival, which was released on September 23, 2014.

sentences: The album's second single, "Til It's Gone", was released in mid-October.

sentences: It reached number one on the Country Airplay chart the week of January 31, 2015.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: The third single "Wild Child", which is a duet with Grace Potter, was released two days later.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: It reached number one on the Country Airplay chart the week of June 27, 2015.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: The album's fourth single, "Save It for a Rainy Day", was released to country radio on June 29, 2015.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: It reached number one on the Country Airplay chart the week of October 9, 2015.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: On October 24, Chesney announced his 2015 tour The Big Revival Tour, which began on March 26, 2015.
section: == Career and awards == | === The Big Revival (2014) ===

sentences: On October 27, he and Jason Aldean announced that they would perform 10 joint stadium shows in the summer of that year.

sentences: No Shoes Nation (2017)
section: == Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===
== Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===

sentences: On August 25, 2012, at Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Massachusetts, Kenny Chesney announced to his fans that he would call his fan following No Shoes Nation.
section: == Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===

sentences: The term No Shoes Nation originated from Chesney's hit song "No Shoes, No Shirt, No Problem".
section: == Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===

sentences: The symbol of No Shoes Nation is a black flag with a white skull and crossbones.
section: == Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===

sentences: The name was accompanied by a live album called Live in No Shoes Nation, which topped the Billboard 200 after its release in late 2017.
section: == Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===

sentences: No Shoes Nation inspired the name of Chesney's Sirius XM channel, No Shoes Radio.
section: == Career and awards == | === No Shoes Nation (2017) ===

sentences: Here and Now (2020) ===
section: == Career and awards == | === Here and Now (2020) ===

sentences: In March 2020, he announced a new album called Here and Now, which features the title track and "Tip of My Tongue", a leadoff single that was released in mid-2019.
section: == Career and awards == | === Here and Now (2020) ===

sentences: The album debuted at number one and became Chesney's 16th top 10 album on the US Billboard 200, with 233,000 units.
section: == Career and awards == | === Here and Now (2020) ===
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In 2000, Chesney and Tim McGraw became involved in a scuffle with police officers in Buffalo, New York, after Chesney attempted to ride a police horse.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: McGraw came to Chesney's aid after police officers nearby believed the horse was being stolen.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The two were arrested and charged, Chesney for disorderly conduct and McGraw for assault, but were acquitted in 2001.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On May 9, 2005, Chesney married actress Renée Zellweger in a ceremony on the island of St. John.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They had met in January at a tsunami relief event.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: On September 15 of that same year, after only four months of marriage, they announced their plans for an annulment.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Zellweger cited fraud as the reason in the related papers, and after media scrutiny of her use of the word "fraud," she qualified the use of the term, stating that it was "simply legal language and not a reflection of Kenny's character."
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Chesney later suggested the failure of his marriage was due to "the fact that I panicked."
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In an interview by 60 Minutes with Anderson Cooper, Chesney commented on the failed marriage, "The only fraud that was committed was me thinking that I knew what it was like… that I really understood what it was like to be married, and I really didn't."
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: The annulment was finalized in late December 2005.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Since 2012, Chesney has dated Mary Nolan.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Not much is known about their relationship, largely due to past media scrutiny and the couple's decision to lead a private life.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Nolan has attended Award shows with Chesney.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In 2015, Forbes estimated Chesney's annual income at $42 million.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Philanthropy =
section: == Personal life == | === Philanthropy ===
== Personal life == | === Philanthropy ===

sentences: In 2017, Chesney came to the aid of the U.S. and British Virgin Islands victims of Hurricane Irma, one of whom was given a free lift to the mainland United States.
section: == Personal life == | === Philanthropy ===

sentences: Chesney owns a mansion on St. John in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where many stayed to weather the storm.
section: == Personal life == | === Philanthropy ===

sentences: Chesney also set up a charitable fund, Love for Love City, to help victims of the storm.
section: == Personal life == | === Philanthropy ===

sentences: Chesney will donate all proceeds from "Songs for the Saints" to the fund.
section: == Personal life == | === Philanthropy ===
